Wedbush analyst Dan Ives raised Tesla’s price target from $350 to $500 . The price hike is part of Ives’ larger vision for the company: a possible $2 trillion market cap by the end of 2026 . The potential catalyst? The long-promised launch of Tesla's robotaxi service, which CEO Elon Musk claims will debut in June .  Ives sees Tesla as a platform positioned to capitalize on the convergence of autonomous driving and AI . Ives said AI and autonomous are worth at least $1 trillion for Tesla . The automaker could eventually become one of the best pure plays on AI over the next decade .  Tesla’s FSD system has faced regulatory scrutiny and safety concerns for years . Ives speculated that the close ties between Musk and President Donald Trump could help pave the way for fewer regulatory hurdles .  “and neither will Tesla’s autonomous and robotics strategic vision” “ and neither will neither will the company,” Tesla said in a statement .

Goldman Sachs chief information officer Marco Argenti says AI is just another transition . "It elevates your work rather than doing repetitive tasks," he says . Before joining Goldman Sachs, he was involved in tech integration across several departments within Amazon's cloud services division .  Argenti joined Goldman Sachs in 2019, just as AI was beginning its rise in everyday use . "I would estimate that at this moment, close to two-thirds of the organization in one way or another is exposed to an AI tool," he said .  Of companies using AI, 37% said the technology would replace some of their workers . In 2024, 44% of employers would "definitely or probably" lay off workers due to AI . Yet, Argenti envisions a world where humans and machines coexist .  Goldman Sachs has 12,000 developers within Goldman Sachs out of 45,000 people . "I think that will be the same for AI, except there is a certain velocity," he said .

Tesla shares have surged, fueled by big expectations for the automaker's upcoming Robotaxi platform . Elon Musk believes its autonomous ride-sharing network, once launched, could scale quickly . The automaker reported a huge decline in earnings per share in its first quarter .  Tesla CEO Elon Musk is extremely bullish on the company's plans for autonomous ride sharing . "My prediction is that, probably by the end of next year, we'll have ... hundreds of thousands if not over a million Teslas doing self-driving in the U.S.," Musk said .  Tesla plans to launch its Robotaxi service in Austin this June . The service will be very small at first . Once it is proved to be safe, the company will scale up the service .  Tesla has a habit of turning long-shot ideas into market-shifting products . But investors would be wise to temper expectations . Developing and deploying autonomous vehicles at scale is one of the most complex engineering challenges in the world .  Shares now trade at a price-to-earnings ratio of about 193, a valuation that prices in extraordinary earnings growth for the foreseeable future . If Musk's ambitious vision for an autonomous ride-sharing network goes as well as he expects it to, the stock could have more room to run . Third Point's billionaire chief dumped his fund's entire stake in Tesla in the first quarter . Loeb loaded up on the most direct beneficiary of the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution .  May 15 marked the filing deadline for 13Fs detailing trading activity for the March-ended quarter . Third Point's Dan Loeb completely kicked North America's electric-vehicle (EV) kingpinTesla . Loeb closed out the first frame of 2025 with $6.55 billion in AUM which was spread across 45 stocks .  Dan Loeb completely exited nine positions at Third Point during the first quarter . The sale of 500,000 shares of Tesla is what stands out most . The average stock in Loeb's portfolio has an average hold time of 13 months .  EV revenue plunged 20% in the first quarter from the prior-year period . Tesla's vehicle margin has been trending lower for the last two years . More than half of Tesla's pre-tax income can be traced to automotive regulatory credits . Even with steep price cuts, Tesla has struggled to keep its EV inventory levels rising .  Dan Loeb might be out due to Elon Musk's numerous unfulfilled promises . Tesla's chief has claimed that Level 5 full self-driving is "one year away" for the last 11 years . Without automotive regulatory credits, Tesla would have reported a pre-tax loss in the March-ended quarter .  The last time Third Point's billionaire investor held shares of Nvidia for his fund was the second quarter of 2023 . During the first quarter of 2025, Loeb scooped up 1,450,000 shares, valued at almost $196 million . No company has been a more direct beneficiary of the AI revolution than Nvidia .  Both Nvidia's Hopper and Blackwell GPUs are commanding a premium to competing chips . Even the CUDA software platform is doing its part to make Nvidia one of Wall Street's most-influential businesses . Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio dipped to around 19 in March .  Nvidia stock isn't guaranteed to head higher . Every next-big-thing trend for more than three decades has worked its way through a bubble-bursting event early in its expansion . The simple fact that most businesses lack a well-defined AI game plan and aren't generating a profit on their AI investments signals that investors have, once again overestimated the adoption rate and utility of another game-changing technology . President Donald Trump dug in on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on the European Union . Trump said a potential 25% charge on smartphones would apply to all foreign-made devices . The president downplayed the ability of the EU to avoid a higher tariff rate, which he said would hit June 1 .  The S&P 500 dropped 0.7%, down for a fourth straight day . Apple led a selloff in tech, falling more than 3% . Trump said he was “not looking for a deal” with Brussels .  Trump dismissed concerns that his moves could result in higher prices for Americans . He said foreign countries and companies could absorb the cost of the tariffs . Still, he acknowledged that some costs could be passed on to consumers . The defiant tone came despite top administration officials saying earlier Friday that Trump was trying to drive US trading partners to strike better deals .  US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent expressed hope “this would light a fire under the EU. EU” The pivot was a notable change in tone from a G.7 finance ministers’ meeting earlier this week . Separately, Trump posted to social media that he already told Apple the company’s popular smartphones should be made in the US .  The EU’s trade chief, Maros Sefcovic, held a call with his US counterpart, Jamieson Greer, on Friday to take stock of negotiations . The commission “remains ready to work in good faith,” the commission said in a social media post . Irish Prime Minister Micheal Martin called Trump's suggestion “enormously disappointing”  New EU framework covers tariff and non-tariff barriers, ways to enhance economic security, mutual investments, strategic purchases and cooperation on global challenges . Aim of the paper was sent to the White House earlier this week, was to jump-start formal trade negotiations .  The EU is aiming to cooperate with the US, and is seeking a balanced and mutually beneficial deal . EU officials and many member states remain skeptical that the Trump administration is driven by similar goals . The EU plans to move forward with preparing countermeasures if negotiations fail to produce a satisfactory outcome .  “We are maintaining the same line: de-escalation, but we are ready to respond,” French trade minister Laurent Saint-Martin posted Friday . Trump lowered his so-called reciprocal rate on most EU exports to 10% from 20% for same amount of time .

President Donald Trump said the tariffs he threatened against Apple Inc. earlier Friday would also be aimed at a wider range of device makers . Trump indicated that the import levies would be “appropriately done” and ready for implementation by the end of June .  Trump’s demand for US-based manufacturing pose a stark challenge to Apple and Samsung, whose supply chains for their devices have been concentrated in Asia for years . Trump also threatened a 50% tariff on the European Union that would go into effect June 1, which weighed on the broader market .  Trump’s warning on Friday took shape after Apple signaled earlier this month that new tariffs would bring as much as $900 million in higher costs in the current quarter . Apple had already planned to transfer the bulk of its US-bound iPhone production to facilities in India .  Apple said earlier this year that it plans to spend $500 billion in the US over the next four years . Moving manufacturing of its signature iPhone and other devices to the US would be an enormous and expensive undertaking for Cupertino, California-based Apple .  The change threatens to cut Apple’s gross margin by 3 to 3.5 percentage points in fiscal 2026 . But moving iPhone production to the US would likely still be far more costly than paying the tariff . The S&P 500 sealed its steepest weekly fall since March . European and U.S. stocks slumped . The downside for risky assets is "manageable", says Citi . But large doses of uncertainty and risk have been injected back into markets . The proposed class action, filed in federal court in Seattle, targets 18 different rice varieties sold through Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) The legal action follows a recent study by the nonprofit Healthy Babies, Bright Futures, which found traces of arsenic in all 145 rice samples tested across the US . The plaintiffs claim they would have avoided purchasing Iberia Basmati rice .  The lawsuit seeks at least $5 million in damages, citing violations of consumer protection laws . Similar lawsuits have previously targeted makers of baby food and dark chocolate for the presence of heavy metals . AMZN is down by nearly 9% since the start of 2025 . President Trump said Friday that U.S. Steel will keep its headquarters in Pittsburgh as part of what he called a “planned partnership” that seemed to signal that he’ll approve a bid by Japan-based Nippon Steel . Investors seemed to take Trump's statement as a sign that he's approving some sort of merger .  Nippon Steel's $15 billion bid to buy U.S. Steel was blocked by Joe Biden on his way out of office . It wasn't clear what the terms of the deal would be or who would control the arrangement . Neither company explained how the partnership would work .  Japan’s chief tariff negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said he was closely watching the development . Shares of U.S. Steel jumped 21% on the news, and continued rising in aftermarket trading .  Nippon Steel had offered up a $2.7 billion commitment to upgrade U.S. Steel's two blast furnaces and pledged that it wouldn't import steel slabs that would compete with the facilities . The Japanese company also pledged not to conduct layoffs or plant closings during the term of the existing labor agreement .  Trump said he was "totally against the once great and powerful U.S. Steel being bought by a foreign company" Last month, Trump ordered a new national security review of Nippon Steel’s proposed bid .

Shares of U.S. Steel (NYSE:X) climbed 23% today following President Donald Trump's announcement of the company’s decision to keep its headquarters in the United States . The move is expected to generate significant economic benefits, including the creation of approximately 70,000 jobs .  The planned partnership between U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel is set to reinforce the company’s presence in the US . The market has responded favorably to the news, it is important to note that the details of the partnership are yet to be fully disclosed .

Dollar Spot Index fell as much as 0.8% on Friday, extending a more-than-7% decline since the beginning of the year . The dollar is down for a fourth day in five after Trump’s latest threats of tariffs . Hedge funds, asset managers and other speculative traders continued to bet against the dollar .  The Canadian loonie strengthened to as much as 1.3709 per US currency, its strongest level since October . Seven currencies out of the group rose 1% or more against the greenback during Friday’s trading, with New Zealand and Australian dollars leading advances .  Speculative traders trimmed their positioning to $12.4 billion in the week ending May 20 from $16.5 billion in a week prior . Some of the angst has come as the Senate considers the tax bill, which includes a debt ceiling increase .  Investors are more wary of US assets and that is continuing to weigh on the dollar, a Rabobank strategist says . “Whether it be budget, inflation or growth concerns, investors are wary of U.S. assets,” she says .

Stock markets dipped slightly Friday after Trump threatened a 50% tax on imports from the European Union as well as a 25% surcharge on products from Apple . The S&P 500 notched a daily decrease of 0.7% and a weekly drop of 1.7%. The Nasdaq had a daily decline of 1%, and the Dow Jones fell 0.6%.  On April 2, the 47th president unveiled a base 10% tax on imports from the U.S.’s trading partners, as well as more severe tariffs on dozens of countries, especially China . The stock and bond markets shuddered in response, and Trump walked back his tariff plans soon after . Last week, the markets rallied and posted a weekly gain .  Moody’s rating of U.S. credit has also weighed on markets . The credit ratings agency dropped its ranking of American debt from AAA to a rating of one rung below at Aa1 .

Investors are increasingly drawn to aerospace leaders BoeingBA and Airbus . The companies’ strong presence across both commercial aviation and defense sectors positions them well to capitalize on this growth . Boeing maintains a diversified business portfolio that includes commercial aircraft, defense systems, and space technologies .  Boeing delivered more commercial jets in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the previous year . Boeing also successfully reduced its operating cash outflow to $1.62 billion from $3.36 billion . Boeing held $23.67 billion in cash and equivalents, with current debt of $7.93 billion, well below its cash balance .  Boeing shows signs of steady recovery and growth, bolstered by strong defense contracts and improving commercial operations . Boeing’s Defense, Space & Security division further strengthens revenue prospects with a substantial backlog of $61.57 billion as of March 31, 2025 . Airbus, on the other hand, has maintained more financial stability in recent times .  Airbus’ commercial aircraft deliveries outpaced Boeing’s for the fifth consecutive year, reinforcing its market leadership . Boeing faces significant execution and reputational risks, mainly due to ongoing quality .  As of March 31, 2025, Boeing held around 35 undelivered 737-8 aircraft produced before 2023, scheduled for delivery this year . 25 of these jets are destined for Chinese customers, raising concerns about timely deliveries amid escalating U.S.-China trade tensions . Failure in delivering these aircraft on time could negatively impact Boeing’s Commercial Airplanes segment, potentially leading to weaker financial performance in the upcoming quarters .  Boeing (up 13%) has outperformed EADSY (up 6.4%) over the past three months and has done the same in the past year . Boeing (ups 13%) outperformed Airbus (up 8.4%) Shares of BA have surged 18.1% in the last year . The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Airbus’ 2025 sales implies a year-over-year surge of 10.4%.  EADSY is trading at a forward sales multiple of 1.68X, below BA’s 1.73X . Boeing's Return on Invested Capital (“ROIC”) came in below EAD SY's . BA's ROIC suggests that the jet giant is not generating enough profit from its investments to cover the cost of its capital .  Airbus holds a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy), while Boeing carries a Zack Rank #3 (Hold) Airbus has a ZACK Rank of 2 (Buy) and Boeing has a Rank of 3 (Hold). Risk-averse investors looking for better stability and capital efficiency may add EADSY to their portfolio .

A union has been certified at a Whole Foods Market store in Philadelphia, marking a US first for the Amazon.com grocery chain . The decision tees up a legal battle . Whole Foods says the union “illegally interfered with our team members’ right to a fair vote” at the store .  Whole Foods argued the union made promises and provided free car rides to workers that prevented a fair election . The union has denied wrongdoing . Whole Foods can appeal the case to the labor board’s members in Washington DC .  The UFCW on Friday urged Whole Foods to begin collective bargaining . That body currently lacks the three-member quorum required to issue rulings . President Donald Trump fired Democratic member Gwynne Wilcox, but a Thursday ruling from the US Supreme Court allows the president to oust her for now . Trump said at the White House he was “not looking for a deal” with the EU .  Wall Street in recent weeks had begun to shift focus away from tariffs and toward Trump’stax bill . But the new threat of tariffs on the EU was a sharp reminder that policy uncertainty remains .  The S&P 500 sank in early April after Trump announced massive “reciprocal” tariffs, and rebounded sharply after the president a week later announced a 90-day pause on most of them . Investors have been on edge about potential developments during the 90 day pause, which is set to end in July .  Apple's market value dipped back below the $3 trillion mark on Friday . The tech giant has tumbled 22% this year as it has been caught in the crossfire of Trump’s trade war . Retirement plans like 401(k)s are often invested in funds that track the S&P 500 .  The yield on the 10-year Treasury note on Friday edged lower to 4.51% as investors scooped up bonds amid renewed trade uncertainty . “Markets are looking for a little more fiscal discipline, they’re concerned,” Federal Reserve Governor Chris Waller said .  The S&P 500 posted its fourth day of losses in a row as the recent rebound in US markets has stalled . The benchmark index is down slightly on the year . Trump’s threat of a higher tariff for the region could go into effect June 1 .

Goldman Sachs chief information officer Marco Argenti says AI is just another transition . "It elevates your work rather than doing repetitive tasks," he says . Before joining Goldman Sachs, he was involved in tech integration across several departments within Amazon's cloud services division .  Argenti joined Goldman Sachs in 2019, just as AI was beginning its rise in everyday use . "I would estimate that at this moment, close to two-thirds of the organization in one way or another is exposed to an AI tool," he said .  Of companies using AI, 37% said the technology would replace some of their workers . In 2024, 44% of employers would "definitely or probably" lay off workers due to AI . Yet, Argenti envisions a world where humans and machines coexist .  Goldman Sachs has 12,000 developers within Goldman Sachs out of 45,000 people . "I think that will be the same for AI, except there is a certain velocity," he said .

Tesla shares have surged, fueled by big expectations for the automaker's upcoming Robotaxi platform . Elon Musk believes its autonomous ride-sharing network, once launched, could scale quickly . The automaker reported a huge decline in earnings per share in its first quarter .  Tesla CEO Elon Musk is extremely bullish on the company's plans for autonomous ride sharing . "My prediction is that, probably by the end of next year, we'll have ... hundreds of thousands if not over a million Teslas doing self-driving in the U.S.," Musk said .  Tesla plans to launch its Robotaxi service in Austin this June . The service will be very small at first . Once it is proved to be safe, the company will scale up the service .  Tesla has a habit of turning long-shot ideas into market-shifting products . But investors would be wise to temper expectations . Developing and deploying autonomous vehicles at scale is one of the most complex engineering challenges in the world .  Shares now trade at a price-to-earnings ratio of about 193, a valuation that prices in extraordinary earnings growth for the foreseeable future . If Musk's ambitious vision for an autonomous ride-sharing network goes as well as he expects it to, the stock could have more room to run . Third Point's billionaire chief dumped his fund's entire stake in Tesla in the first quarter . Loeb loaded up on the most direct beneficiary of the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution .  May 15 marked the filing deadline for 13Fs detailing trading activity for the March-ended quarter . Third Point's Dan Loeb completely kicked North America's electric-vehicle (EV) kingpinTesla . Loeb closed out the first frame of 2025 with $6.55 billion in AUM which was spread across 45 stocks .  Dan Loeb completely exited nine positions at Third Point during the first quarter . The sale of 500,000 shares of Tesla is what stands out most . The average stock in Loeb's portfolio has an average hold time of 13 months .  EV revenue plunged 20% in the first quarter from the prior-year period . Tesla's vehicle margin has been trending lower for the last two years . More than half of Tesla's pre-tax income can be traced to automotive regulatory credits . Even with steep price cuts, Tesla has struggled to keep its EV inventory levels rising .  Dan Loeb might be out due to Elon Musk's numerous unfulfilled promises . Tesla's chief has claimed that Level 5 full self-driving is "one year away" for the last 11 years . Without automotive regulatory credits, Tesla would have reported a pre-tax loss in the March-ended quarter .  The last time Third Point's billionaire investor held shares of Nvidia for his fund was the second quarter of 2023 . During the first quarter of 2025, Loeb scooped up 1,450,000 shares, valued at almost $196 million . No company has been a more direct beneficiary of the AI revolution than Nvidia .  Both Nvidia's Hopper and Blackwell GPUs are commanding a premium to competing chips . Even the CUDA software platform is doing its part to make Nvidia one of Wall Street's most-influential businesses . Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio dipped to around 19 in March .  Nvidia stock isn't guaranteed to head higher . Every next-big-thing trend for more than three decades has worked its way through a bubble-bursting event early in its expansion . The simple fact that most businesses lack a well-defined AI game plan and aren't generating a profit on their AI investments signals that investors have, once again overestimated the adoption rate and utility of another game-changing technology .
